title-group.article-title: Coccinellid predators of mealybugs infesting banana in South India, including a new species and a new record of Scymnus Kugelann (Coleoptera: Coccinellidae), with notes on other natural enemies

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Coccinellid predators of mealybugs infesting banana in South India , including a new species and a new record of
Scymnus Kugelann
( Coleoptera : Coccinellidae ), with notes on other natural enemies

J. POORANI 1, 2, * , C. ANURADHA 1, 3 ,
R . THANIGAIRAJ
1, 4 & P. PRASHINA MOL 1, 5

1
ICAR-National Research Centre for Banana, Thogamalai Road, Thayanur Post, Tiruchirappalli-620102, Tamil Nadu , India 2
�
pooranij@outlook.com ; https://orcid.org/ 0000-0003-3879-3264

3
�
anuradha.chelliah@gmail.com ; https://orcid.org/ 0000-0002-8534-9345

�

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
Several species of mealybugs infest various parts of bananas and plantains including foliage, fruits, rhizome and roots in all the major banana growing regions of India and cause moderate to occasionally serious damage but systematic attempts at documenting the mealybug pests of banana and their natural enemies are lacking in India . In this study, mealybugs infesting bananas and plantains in Tamil Nadu , South India , are documented along with their coccinellid predators and other natural enemies. The exotic Jack Beardsley mealybug,
Pseudococcus jackbeardsleyi Gimpel & Miller
, was found to be a major pest of banana bunches in all localities surveyed in Tamil Nadu and the grey pineapple mealybug,
Dysmicoccus neobrevipes Beardsley
, was a serious pest in some isolated pockets. Three coccinellids,
Scymnus ( Pullus ) coccivora Ramakrishna Ayyar
,
Nephus regularis Sicard and Slipinskiscymnus
saciformis (Motschulsky) were found to be the major predators of all species of mealybugs.
Brumoides suturalis (Fabricius)
was predatory on solenopsis mealybug (
Phenacoccus solenopsis Tinsley
) only and
Hyperaspis maindroni Sicard
was associated with solenopsis mealybug and pink pineapple mealybug (
Dysmicoccus brevipes (Cockerell))
. One new species,
Scymnus ( Pullus ) spicatus
sp. n.
, is described as a predator of Jack Beardsley mealybug and striped mealybug (
Ferrisia virgata (Cockerell))
.
Scymnus ( Pullus ) syoitii Sasaji, 1971
, a Japanese species, is recorded for the first time from India as a predator of banana root mealybugs in Tamil Nadu and on
Planococcus citri (Risso)
in Karnataka . Brief notes on the other natural enemies of banana mealybugs are also given with illustrations.

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Key words: Banana , mealybugs , natural enemies , Coccinelloidea ,
Scymnini
,
new species

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Several mealybugs ( Hemiptera : Sternorrhyncha: Pseudococcidae , Rhizoecidae ) are commonly associated with bananas and plantains and infest almost all the major plant parts including rhizome, roots, foliage, fruits, and rarely, the pseudostem. As many as 41 species of Pseudococcidae and 8 species of Rhizoecidae (previously included in Pseudococcidae ) are associated with
Musa spp.
worldwide (
). Mealybugs may play a role in the transmission of virus diseases of banana and some species such as
Dysmicoccus brevipes (Cockerell)
,
Planococcus citri (Risso)
,
Planococcus ficus (Signoret)
,
Pseudococcus longispinus (Targioni Tozzetti)
, and
Ferrisia virgata (Cockerell)
, have been found to be semi-persistent vectors of Banana Streak Virus (
). The Jack Beardsley mealybug,
Pseudococcus jackbeardsleyi Gimpel & Miller
, an exotic pest of Neotropical origin, is an emerging pest of banana fruits in many parts of Tamil Nadu , South India (unpublished data). Mealybug infestation on fruits reduces the market value of bunches, fetches poor returns to banana farmers and has adverse implications for banana exports from India . In South India , yield losses due to banana mealybugs are usually mild to moderate with occasional heavy crop losses caused mainly by fruit and root mealybugs but very little information is available on the mealybug species, their pest status, natural enemies, and the extent of economic damage due to mealybugs has not been systematically assessed.

This study documents the mealybug species infesting banana and their natural enemies, particularly coccinellid beetles ( Coleoptera : Coccinellidae ), based on extensive surveys carried out during 2015–2023. Illustrated notes are provided on coccinellid predators of banana mealybugs and their common parasitoids. One new species of
Scymnus ( Pullus ) Mulsant
found to be predatory on the invasive Jack Beardsley mealybug and striped mealybug is described from Tamil Nadu.
Scymnus ( Pullus ) syoitii Sasaji, 1971
, a species hitherto known only from Japan , is recorded from India for the first time in association with banana root mealybugs. Brief illustrated notes are also given on the other natural enemies of banana mealybugs.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: Field collection and characterization of mealybugs

Mealybug infested parts, including fruits, were collected from banana orchards in about 40 locations in eight districts of Tamil Nadu , Southern India , and also from the research farm of ICAR–National Research Centre for Banana (ICAR– NRCB ), Trichy, along with the details of the affected cultivars ( Table 1 ). The mealybug samples were brought to the laboratory for documentation of the mealybug species complex and for observations on the associated natural enemies, particularly coccinellids. Permanent slide mounts of mealybugs were made and identified using the keys given by
. Permanent slide mounts of the mealybugs are deposited in the banana insect collection maintained at the ICAR– NRCB .

sec.title: Collection and characterization of natural enemies of banana mealybugs
sec.p: The following measurements were taken for the coccinellids: TL—total length, length from apical margin of clypeus to apex of elytra; TW—total width, width across both elytra at widest point; HW—head width in frontal view, including eyes; PL —pronotal length, from middle of anterior margin to base of pronotum; PW —pronotal width at widest point; EL—elytral length, from the apex of the elytra to the base including the scutellum; EW— elytral width, equal TW. Type material of the new species of coccinellid will be deposited in the collections of ICAR–National Bureau of Agricultural Insect Resources, Bangalore (ICAR–NBAIR).

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: Mealybug complex on banana in Tamil Nadu , South India

The mealybug complex of bananas and plantains observed in different parts of Tamil Nadu in the surveys conducted during 2015–2023 is summarized in Table 2 . Totally 15 species were found to feed on various parts of banana. Six species, namely,
Rastrococcus iceryoides (Green)
( Fig. 1a, b ),
Ferrisia virgata (Cockerell)
( Fig. 1c, d ),
Maconellicoccus hirsutus (Green)
( Fig. 1e, f ),
Pseudococcus jackbeardsleyi Gimpel & Miller
(
Fig. 1g , h
),
Dysmicoccus neobrevipes Beardsley
( Fig. 2c, d ), and
Planococcus lilacinus (Cockerell)
( Fig. 2a, b ), were found to infest banana bunches and fruits, with the last being the least common species causing low to moderate levels of damage in isolated pockets. Several popular commercial banana cultivars and germplasm accessions in the field gene bank of banana maintained in the research farm of ICAR-NRCB and other localities, viz . Karpuravalli, Ash Monthan, Grand Nain, Poovan, Ney Poovan, and Namwa Khom, and Sabah, were found to be the most affected.
Dysmicoccus brevipes (Cockerell)
( Figs 3c, d ; 4a, b ) was found to infest both subterranean and aerial plant parts, including the rhizome, roots, peduncle, pseudostem, bracts, and to a lesser extent, foliage and fruits.
Ferrisia virgata
and
R. iceryoides
were found to feed on banana foliage in addition to fruits, with only the former causing moderately significant level of leaf damage. Four species,
Phenacoccus solenopsis Tinsley
( Fig. 3a, b ),
Rastrococcus invadens Williams
( Fig. 3e, f ),
Paracoccus marginatus Williams & Granara de Willink
(
Fig. 3g
), and
Planococcus minor (Maskell)
( Fig. 4c, d ) were found to infest banana foliage at low or negligible levels and
P. marginatus
was usually found in mixed infestations of mealybugs. One giant mealybug,
Icerya seychellarum (Westwood)
( Fig. 3h ) (Coccoidea: Margarodidae ) was recorded at very low levels. Three species of root mealybugs (Coccoidea: Rhizoecidae ), namely,
Geococcus?johorensis Williams
( Fig. 4e, f ), an apparently new species of
Geococcus
, and a
Rhizoecus sp.
(
Fig. 4g , h
) were found to be the major root mealybugs.

In our surveys, we observed moderate to severe infestation of the exotic Jack Beardsley mealybug,
P. jackbeardsleyi ,
on banana bunches and fruits of popular banana cultivars in Tamil Nadu . It was first recorded in India in 2013 on papaya (
) and since then it has been recorded on several host plants in the states of Tamil Nadu and Karnataka (
). The Jack Beardsley mealybug is closely related to and often misidentified as the banana mealybug,
Pseudococcus elisae Borchsenius
and the latter is “with few exceptions, known only from banana and is restricted to the area of northern South America and Central America and Florida” (
). The Jack Beardsley mealybug is found in 59 countries; it is highly polyphagous and known to infest 115 genera of plants in 54 families across the world (
). It has spread to many other parts of the world in South and South East Asia , Hawaii, etc. Live specimens of
P. jackbeardsleyi
also resemble
P. longispinus (Targioni Tozzetti)
, a species commonly distributed in India . The Jack Beardsley mealybug is morphologically well characterized and can be reliably identified using the descriptions given by
,
, and
. Though
P. jackbeardsleyi
is known to be most commonly associated with banana in its native range (
) and its type material was also collected on the fruits of
Musa sp.
in Mexico (
), it has not been reported as a pest of banana so far in India . This constitutes the first report of its occurrence as a major banana pest from India .

Among other fruit mealybugs,
Dysmicoccus neobrevipes
causes moderate to serious damage in some pockets of Karur district in Tamil Nadu, leading to extensive crop loss on a scale greater than that caused by the Jack Beardsley mealybug and visually manifested in the form of symptoms. The affected fruits had large blackish patches or were fully discolored, leading to total loss of market value. Extensive damage was observed wherever
Sesbania grandiflora
(L.), a fodder legume tree, was grown on the borders of banana fields as
D. neobrevipes
infested
Sesbania
also. Both
D. neobrevipes
and
P. jackbeardsleyi
have been recorded as banana pests from the Philippines and classified as mealybugs of quarantine significance to the whole of Australia (
).
Dysmicoccus neobrevipes
has been earlier recorded as a banana pest from Karnataka , South India . The mealybugs and their natural enemies documented in this study are listed in Table 2 . Detailed factsheets with information on the diagnosis, nomenclature, hosts, distribution, natural enemies and pertinent literature on the mealybugs listed here are available on ScaleNet (
), a global database on Coccoidea.

sec.title: Coccinellid predators of banana fruit mealybugs
sec.p:
Three species of coccinellids, all belonging to the tribe Scymnini [
Scymnus ( Pullus ) coccivora Ramakrishna Ayyar, 1925
( Fig. 5a, b ),
Nephus regularis Sicard, 1929
( Fig. 5c, d ) and Slipinskiscymnus saciformis (
) (
Fig. 5g
)] were found to feed on all mealybugs infesting banana in Tamil Nadu .
Hyperaspis maindroni Sicard, 1929
( Fig. 5e, f ) [Tribe Hyperaspidini , on
D. brevipes
and
P. solenopsis
],
Brumoides suturalis ( Fabricius, 1798 )
( Fig. 5h ) [Tribe Chilocorini , on
P. solenopsis
], and
Novius fumidus ( Mulsant, 1850 )
[Tribe Noviini , on
Icerya seychellarum (Westwood)
] were the other coccinellids commonly recorded on banana.A new species of
Scymnus ( Pullus ) Mulsant
was found to be predatory on the Jack Beardsley mealybug and
F. virgata .
Larvae and adults of
Scymnus ( Pullus ) syoitii Sasaji
, a Japanese species, were found in association with root mealybugs of banana and it is a new addition to the Scymnini fauna of India . They are described and illustrated here.

mixed-citation.named-content: Coccinellid predators of mealybugs infesting banana in South India, including a new species and a new record of Scymnus Kugelann (Coleoptera: Coccinellidae), with notes on other natural enemies

tp:taxon-treatment.tp:mixed-nomenclature:
Scymnus ( Pullus ) spicatus Poorani
, sp. n.

tp:treatment-sec.p: Etymology. The specific epithet is a Latin adjective in reference to the acutely pointed median tooth on the posterior margin of abdominal ventrite 5 in male.

Material examined .
Holotype male, “ India : Tamil Nadu : Podavur , NRCB research farm, N°1047’20.16” E078°34’29.88” , Ex. Jack Beardsley mealybug on banana, R . Thanigairaj”
;
Paratypes : with same data as holotype, except dates of collection 24.iv.19, 29.i.21, 28.vii.21, 11.viii.21 ( ICAR-NBAIR )
.

Hosts / associated host plants .
Scymnus ( Pullus ) spicatus
sp. n. was collected as a predator of Jack Beardsley mealybug and
F. virgata
infesting banana in and around Trichy, Tamil Nadu . It was also found feeding on
F. virgata
infesting eggplant (
Solanum melongena
L.) in and around the banana orchards at the NRCB research farm.

Notes. Indigenous natural enemies such as
Mallada desjardinsi (Navás)
(=
M. boninensis (Okamoto))
( Neuroptera : Chrysopidae ),
Cryptolaemus montrouzieri Mulsant
( Coleoptera : Coccinellidae ),
Spalgis epeus (Westwood)
( Lepidoptera : Lycaenidae ) and some species of gnats ( Diptera : Cecidomyiidae ) have been recorded earlier as predators of
P. jackbeardsleyi
in Karnataka and Tamil Nadu , South India ( Shylesha 2013 ;
Mani et al. 2013
).

mixed-citation.named-content: Coccinellid predators of mealybugs infesting banana in South India, including a new species and a new record of Scymnus Kugelann (Coleoptera: Coccinellidae), with notes on other natural enemies

tp:treatment-sec.p: Material examined. India: Tamil Nadu : Mullikarumbur, N10°49’34.39” E078°36’41.69” , Ex. Root mealybug complex on banana, 18.ix.21, 22.xii.21, R . Thanigairaj ( ICAR-NRCB : 9); INDIA : I.I.S.C., Bangalore, Karnataka / vii.1992 , Sp. no. 44/ex Planococcus citri IIE 22763/ Scymnus (P.) sp., det. R .G. Booth, 1993/Pres. by Int. Inst. Ent. B.M. 1993 ( BMNH : 2M (genitalia dissected), 1 unsexed).

Prey / associated habitat. Predatory on banana root mealybug complex (comprising
Geococcus ? johorensis Williams
,
Geococcus sp.
and
Rhizoecus sp.
);
Planococcus citri
(label data).

Notes. Sasaji (1971) described it from Kyushu, Japan [see the holotype photo and details in Kyushu University Museum Database [Hiroyuki Sasaji Collection, Catalog no. SH005533, URL: http://db.museum.kyushu-u.ac.jp/ entomology/?wb=det&cl=31&it=5533]. It appears to be a unique and characteristic species of
Scymnus
in South India with a small, distinctly narrow and elongate oval form, head with a wide frons and small, broadly separated eyes, and prosternal carinae that are distinctly divergent posteriorly and the male genitalia are also diagnostic. The specimens collected from Tamil Nadu , fully match Sasaji’s (1971) description and the male genitalia also are almost identical to the illustrations given by Sasaji. The larvae were found to be predatory on banana root mealybug complex (comprising a mixture of
Geococcus?johorensis ,
Geococcus sp.
and
Rhizoecus sp.
). Conspecific specimens collected in association with
Planococcus citri
from Bangalore, Karnataka , by the Commonwealth Institute of Biological Control-Indian Station (Bangalore) in the collections of BMNH were also examined. It is a new addition to the fauna of Scymnini of the Indian region.

sec.title: Notes on common parasitoids of banana fruit mealybugs
sec.p:
Many encyrtid parasitoids and their hyperparasitoids were collected in association with mealybugs infesting banana.
Anagyrus sp.
( Fig. 10c ) and
Gyranusoidea sp.
( Fig. 10e ) ( Hymenoptera : Encyrtidae ) were reared from
R. iceryoides .
Two hyperparasitoids,
Chartocerus sp.
( Hymenoptera : Signiphoridae ) (
Fig. 10g
) and
Promuscidea unfasciativentris (Girault)
( Hymenoptera : Pirenidae ) ( Fig. 10h ), were reared in association with all species of mealybugs.
Anagyrus indicus
( Fig. 10a ),
Gyranusoidea indica Shafee, Alam & Agarwal
( Fig. 10b ),
Blepyrus insularis (Cameron)
( Fig. 10f ) and
Aenasius advena Compere
( Fig. 11a ) ( Hymenoptera : Encyrtidae ) were reared from
F. virgata .
Aenasius arizonensis (Girault)
( Fig. 11b ), a major parasitoid of solenopsis mealybug on various hosts, was collected on banana also.

Most interestingly, two primary parasitoids including an unidentified species of
Anagyrus
( Hymenoptera : Encyrtidae ) ( Fig. 11c–f ) and
Allotropa sp.
( Hymenoptera : Platygastridae ) ( Fig. 11h ) and a hyperparasitoid,
Chartocerus sp.
(
Fig. 11g
), were reared on the Jack Beardsley mealybug, for which there is no record of any parasitoids from any part of the world, including its native range, until now as per the Universal Chalcidoidea Database (
). One dipteran parasitoid,
Cryptochaetum sp.
( Diptera : Cryptochaetidae ), was recorded on
I. seychellarum .

sec.title: Acknowledgements
sec.p: We thank the Indian Council of Agricultural Research, New Delhi , for financial support and the Director, ICARNational Research Centre for Banana, Trichy, for the facilities provided. The reviewer and the subject editor are acknowledged for their critical comments and suggestions for improvement.
